position.marginalia_text: Laurentius Valla, multa[e] vir doctrine, ingenijq[ue] in primis acuti, popularibus in congressibus ac literatorum circulis, ostentanda[e] disciplina[e] iudicatus est fuisse studiosior, ne dicam parùm modestus; vt ijs in circulis multò appareret diligentior, quàm in libris ipsis, quos scriptos reliquit. Cumq[ue] non pauca in Dialecticis adinuenisset, aduersùs horum temporum artis euis magistros; eò sese efferebat palam vt diceret, Nullam esse Logicam pra[e]ter Laurentianam. Iouianus Pontanus.

book.title: De bello neapolitano et de sermone

marginalia.translation: "Lorenzo Valla, a man of great learning and acute ability in the foremost principles, in community assemblies and in the circles of literary people, he was judged to have been more studious of showing displine, lest I say not modest enough; so that he appeared far more diligent in those circles than in the books themselves, which he left behind written. And since he had invented not a few things in his 'Dialectical disputations', contrary to the teachers of this art of those times, consequently he openly raised himself so that he said that there is no logic beyond Valla's."

position.marginalia_text: Seipsum laudare, simplicis, et rudis, vt Glauci Homerici: Vituperare, esurientis, et abiecti; Vt Æsopi: vtrunq[ue] vani, et leuis; vt Thrasonis aut Geta[e]: Cato appellat vno verbo stultum, qui sese laudat, aut culpat: Plutarchus distinquit, de excellenti homine, indignè prouocato, uel iniuriosè tractato: quem non dedecurrit, sua[e] probata[e] Virtutis obiter meminisse: quom[odo] Scipio ad Capitolium vocauit suos Accusatores, tanq[uam], Dijs gratius debituros pro Victorijs suis: Alioqui, vel magnorum virorum fuerit, plurimum facere; minimum de se loqui: Vt Iugurtham commendat Sallustius. Nec stultus, nec ignauus: Homericum Elogium.

marginalia.translation: To praise oneself as simple and wild, as of Glaucus and Homerus: to find fault with hungry and common folk, as of Aesop: both vain and fickle, as of Thrason or the Geta: With one word Cato called a person foolish, who praised or condemned himself: Plutarch distinguised regarding an excellent man, having been provoked unjustly or having been treated insultingly: whom he did not turn to on the way to remember his approved virtue: in the way Scipio summoned his accusers to the Capitol as if they were indebted the gratitude by the Gods for their victories. Otherwise, he was to do many things of great men; to speak least about himself: As Sallust commened to Jugurtha. Neither the foolish nor the idle person: the Homerian inscription.
